page_analysis.text_content:
Projections
Architectural relief features such as bay windows are pleasant additions to a house design and are encouraged. If they meet certain design criteria they do not count toward gross floor area.

Code sections
18.04.030(a)(65)
18.12.040(b)Table 3

Bay windows
Bay windows that meet the design criteria below are considered to be decorative architectural features and do NOT count toward gross floor area.

Design criteria for bay windows that do not count:
• Bottom of feature must be at least 18" above the floor joists
• Exterior supports must be features like corbels and/or brackets rather than solid walls
• At least 50% of the surface is glass

Fig 13 Bay windows

2' max. from bay window surface to facade surface (Typical all)

18" min. from top of floor to bottom of bay window structure

A
Does NOT count

B
Counts because floor joists continue into the bay window

C & D
Count because of exterior skirt wall (angled or straight)

E
Counts because the surface is not at least 50% glass

Note: Bay windows that extend higher than the structure's roof are considered to be dormers and count toward gross floor area.

visual_elements.description: Five side-view architectural diagrams labeled A, B, C & D, and E illustrating different bay window designs and their compliance with gross floor area counting rules. Diagram A shows a bay window with a bottom feature at least 18" above floor joists and exterior supports like corbels/brackets, labeled 'Does NOT count'. Diagram B shows a bay window where floor joists continue into the bay window, labeled 'Counts'. Diagrams C & D show bay windows with exterior skirt walls (angled or straight), labeled 'Count'. Diagram E shows a bay window with surface less than 50% glass, labeled 'Counts'. Annotations indicate a maximum 2' projection from bay window surface to facade surface and minimum 18" height from floor to bottom of bay window structure.
visual_elements.location: Middle of the page, below the design criteria text

visual_elements.description: Gray shaded box with note: 'Bay windows that extend higher than the structure's roof are considered to be dormers and count toward gross floor area.'
visual_elements.location: Right side of the page, middle

visual_elements.description: Vertical gray sidebar on left side with heading 'Projections' and text encouraging architectural relief features such as bay windows, noting they do not count toward gross floor area if they meet design criteria. Also includes code section references: 18.04.030(a)(65) and 18.12.040(b)Table 3.

technical_specifications.parameter: Maximum projection from bay window surface to facade surface

subheadings: Design criteria for bay windows that do not count

additional_notes: Page number 18 at bottom left corner.
No handwritten annotations or stamps detected.
Text and diagrams are clear and legible.

qualifiers.text: Bay windows that meet the design criteria below are considered to be decorative architectural features and do NOT count toward gross floor area.

conditions.text: Bottom of feature must be at least 18" above the floor joists
Exterior supports must be features like corbels and/or brackets rather than solid walls
At least 50% of the surface is glass

logical_relationships.expression: Bottom of feature must be at least 18" above the floor joists AND Exterior supports must be features like corbels and/or brackets rather than solid walls AND At least 50% of the surface is glass

execution_sequence.action: Evaluate if bay window meets all design criteria (c1, c2, c3) to determine if it does NOT count toward gross floor area
